_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center, is a wholesale food distribution facility serving over 160 retail stores.  The Fort Wayne Distribution Center has two ammonia refrigeration plants in two separate buildings; one system consisting of 25,000 lbs. controls temperatures in the freezer.  The second system is a 14,000 lb. capacity controlling the temperatures in the perishable building. The refrigeration systems contain  approximately 39,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.

The freezer has frozen product, i.e., meat, ice cream, vegetables, breads, cakes, pre-packaged meals and anything else that can typically be found in the frozen department of any grocery store.  The perishable building products are those items that need temperature control but should not be frozen.  These items might be fresh packaged meats, dairy products and poultry.

The SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.  Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules,

procedures, and practices, which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.

SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library. 

Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library

Incorporates several policies, many policies are included in Volume 1, the remaining are referenced from other training manuals maintained in the facility.

Policies included in Volume 1:

Plan of Employee Participation
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis Program
Employee Training Program
Contractor Qualification Program
Management of Change Program
Pre-Startup Safety Review Program
Policy for Opening the Ammonia Refrigeration System
The Support Personnel Entry Program
Mechanical Integrity Program
Compliance Audit Program
Information Dissemination / Trade Secrets policy

Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, etc.) have been developed. 

Volume 2 incorporates information on the specific system components (pumps, vessels, compressors, evaporators, evaporative condensers, purgers, piping systems, heat exchangers, the emergency ventilation system, and general safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. 

Volume 3 incorporates a complete valve list. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.

Also included in volume 3 is the Process and Instrumentation Diagrams for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are inclu

ded to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.

Volume 4 incorporates a complete set of standard operating procedures, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation of system components, shutting down components as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also, included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associate system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.

Volume 5 contains Operation and Maintenance Information including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventive maintenance procedures.

A 5 year revalidation Process Hazard Analysis was performed in February 2007, which highlighted some deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of priority (Injuries to personnel). Items of a low priority (Process improvements) were budgeted for completion in a timely manner.

SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging of all ammonia system valves and components, a PC / PLC based control system with a graphical operator interface. The ammonia refrigeration system at SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center is a standard compression and evaporation style system.

The ammonia refrigeration systems consists of compressors, vessels, condensers, evaporators, pumps etc.  This applies to both buildings.  Both buildings are in close proximity and therefore, wind direction, other atmospheric conditions and downwind receptors w

ould be identical.

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center is very happy to report that we had no reportable releases at our facility in the last 5 years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



We were also going to mention that the Lincoln School shown on the map is not at that location.

The management of the Fort Wayne Distribution Center recognizes its responsibilities to protect its employees and the physical assets of the corporation and to resume business and service as quickly as possible.  In that regard, we have developed methods that allow for the definition of individual responsibilities and quick access to critical information in a variety of emergency scenarios.

The purpose of the Emergency Response Procedures is to provide the employees of the Fort Wayne Distribution Center with guidelines to follow in the event of an emergency.  In that respect the Emergency Procedures will be used as a training tool for all management personnel located at the Fort Wayne site and the emergency responder volunteers.

The information provided in this document will provide what we believe is the best protection for all employees in the event of an emergency situation.



SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of SUPERVALU, Fort Wayne Distribution Center to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
